div.head: THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY
div.p: The General Assembly has not surprised us. The assurance that its proposals were likely, nay, certain, to be moderate and reasonable, might impose upon visiting M.P.'s, but our opinion of the mentality of that august body has been in every way confirmed. We do not deny that many of its resolutions were commendable -indeed some were excellent. We have not the slightest objection to new rail. ways, canals, girls schools or colleges, on the contrary. But we do object to the proposals for placing the financial and general adminis. tration of the country under the control of a Parliament or of a reorganised General Assembly if either of those bodies — still happily in nubibus-contain the men of whose financial ideas we had more than a glimpse on Sunday. We do not: wish to discuss the question of a Parliament here. We merely wish to point out that the Assem. bly calls for a heavy expenditure on oducation, railways, and school buildings ; it demands the suppression of school fees, the incurring by thọ State of large expenses on numerous beneficial objects, and in the same breath votes the suppression of the date taxa and unanimously opposes a worthy member who suggests that universal free education be introduced, its cost to be covered by a rate levied on agricultural land. In short, the Government is to be asked to spend more and take less than the little it now gets from the average Egyptian tax-payer, unless, indeed, our sages of the Assembly have some wonderful scheme for raising money up their sleeves. Very significant, too, is the fact that those who demand education at all costs refuse to endure the prospect of paying the rates ! What self-sacrifice, what devotion to principle, and what a blow to those who believed that eading Egyptians would submit to a small pecuniary inconvenience for the sake of the children of their poorer neighbours !

We beg our contemporary, the "Egyptian standard," recently launcued amidst the plaudits of that particular section of the Nationalist party which follows Mustapha Pasha Kamel, to devote a little attention to chis subject. Mr. Charles Rudy and Mr. Moloney should have a little sarcasm to pare now and then for Egyptians, or are they compelled by contract to criticise nono but their countrymen and to generalise concerning ufficiale, soldiers, tourists, and Britons in general on the strength of the impoliteness or mmorality of a very limited number of indi

iduals, to the exclusion of all "subject races ?" We bave seen what is to be thought of the inancial proposals of the men who dream of ruling Egypt. Here is a contrast the work of the men who have ruled Egypt:

The abovauts for tbe year 1906 abna that the revenge amounted to £1.5,837 000, and the expenditare to £13.16 ,0 W, tbus leaving a surplus of £2,175, 100. Recent calonlations reveal the tsot that doring the last twenty years, extra rdinary ex: penditure to the extent of £19,303,000 has been inoarred for irrigation, railways and pablic buildings. There is now an apspent balance of £8,702,000 in the Reserve Fand. Also, the Caisse de la Dette holds £3,050,000 as reserve food and working balance. These figures make a total of £31,055,000. Of this amount, only £3,610,000 has been borrowed. The remainder, amounting to €13,455,000, has been provided out of surplas revenue. As regards the continuation of romanera. tive publio works, even when the amount now in the Reserve Fand is expendet, it is estimated that, when the Domains Loan, which has now been reduced to about £1,900,000, is paid off, the land remaining at the disposal of thy Governmont will be worth at least from £ ,0 2,000
to £6,000,000. Need we say that as business men we prefer the performances of a Cromer to the promises of our native confrères.

div.head: AMERICAN CONSULAR AGENCY
NEW AGENT APPOINTED.
div.p: There is to be a change in the American Consular Agency in Alexandria. Mr. James Hewat, who has occupied the position to the great satisfaction of the American Government for 18 years, retires, and is to be succeeded by Mr. Alexander Powell, an American citizen.

Mr. Hewat has received from the Department of State at Washington the assurance that no reason exists for the change, except the new policy of the American Government to fill all consular poritions whenever possible by American citizens. Mr. Iddings, Amorioan Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General at Cairo, has written to Mr. Hewat to thank him formally for his long and faithful services, to assure him of the high esteem in which the Washington authorities hold him, and to express his (Mr. Iddings') own deep regret at the severance of their official relations.
Mr. Powell, who has been Deputy Consul General at Beyrout, has arrived in Alexandria, but has not yet taken possession of his post. He is staying at the New Victoria Hotel, Ramleh.

div.head: LORD CROMER AND TAR EGYPTIAN COTTON MILLS.
div.p: Mr. William Tattersall writes to the "Manchester Gnardian" on the question of the 8 | per cent. Excise daty imposed by the Government on the Egyptian Cotton Mille, and in the course of his letter he says:

"Am I happened to have something to do with the qnestion wben the bow mille started in Egypt, I may perhaps be allowed to say that I made representations to the bomo Government pointing out that, as in the case of India, it would be neopgsary to put on & conntervailing Excise daty of 8 por cent, on all goods manofactured by the Egyptian milla.! I contended that it would be only fair and jn8t that if oar goods entering Bsypt had to pig an import daty of 8 per cent. a counter. . vailing Excise daty should be levied at the mille.

"I am aware that Lord Cromer b48 visited the mills, and that great pressure has been pot opon bim to take off the Excise tax, bat if my information is correct there is no likeli. bood of the Evypriup Gofernment meeting the wishes of the cotton mill shareholders in that country."

div.head: CAIRO MILITARY TOURNAMENT.
div.p: A most saccessfnl Military Toornament was beld at the K 8. C. grounds yesterday, some of the minor events having tak in place on the duy before. The weather was good and the attendance most satirfactory. The profit of the tournament, as is koown, goos to oba rities, and we were glud to see the cause was nohly supported by tho iohabitants of Cairo.

The vaulting on horseback #48 perb +p8| the most popular event with the pab'io and was most cleverly performed by the Ioniskilling Dragoong. The musical drive was also an escellent exbibition of skill and nerve. la tbe obstacle race the obstacles were rather too difficolt, and few were able to complete the coorge. In the tag-of-war the K.0.8. Borderers were successfa', although not as beavy as some of their opponents. In the 100 yde. Sorgt. Mobrstadt was the winner, and Lce Cpl Evans in the mile race. The tent pogging for offisers was carried off by Major Knight. Lieat. Forbet, of the K.0.8.B, being second. Sergeant Zell, tbe Coldstream Guards, won the mile. The lemon cutting for (fficers was won by Mijor Huig. The bayonet teams o'mbat was won hy the Coldstream Gaards Riding and jumping for i ffi zars was won by Major Haig. Pre. Lnyner, of the Coldstream Goards, won the obstacle racé, – a very creditable performance. The Indiakilling Dra. gnone Band played a very choice selection of masio and added to the attractions of the afternoon.

div.head: ANGLO-AMERICAN HOSPITAL.
FUNDS URGENTLY WANTED.
div.p: The balance-sheet and income and expenditare account of the Anglo-American Hospi. tul, Cairo, for the year ending 81-t D com bør, 1906, have jast been issned. They are presented in a somewhat different form to previous years with a view to showing in more detail the heads ander which the money bar been exponded. The income and expenditore B3000bt shows an excess of expenditore over income of L.E. 6 as compared with an excess of expenditure ovor income in the preceding year of L.E. 196. It must be borne in mind, bowever, that tbe o deficits would bave been very considerably inoreased wore it not for the continued generous easport of Sir Erpest ('asset. The patients' fees received during the year ending 31st December amount to 1.B. 1,405, as compared with L.B. 958 for the proceding year, thus showing the Batistaotory increase of L. E. 452, doe chiefly to the increase in the charge from P.T. 80 per diem to P.T.40 per diem made to private patients and to the increased nomber of patients in the hospital. The sabsoriptions amounting to L.E. 688 show an increase of L.E. 148 over the past year.

The expenditure for the year, ofter provid ing the gabstantial som of L.E. 400 for depreciation of buildings, fornitore, eto., amoopts to LE 8 25s, as compared with L.E 2,575 for the preceding year. The increase of L.E. 680 in due pripoipally to the largely increased Domber of patients, who amounted to 283 as compared with 194 in 1915. There was also the exceptionally heavy expenditure amnnnt. ing to poarly LE. 200 on repairs and renewals, which in the prere ting year only amounted to I.E. 89. The year 1916 sbows & deoroese in tied fisit of L.E. 190 over the pre eding year, Closing practically with the income and expon. ditnre balanced.

Notwithstanding this apparently satisfactory Bate of aff.irs, it is essential that forthor funds be forthooming it the hospital is to be placed upon a sound financial basis, as owing to the continually increasing demand for beds in the hospital, it will be necessary to provide Moraased accommodation. Foods must also be provided for completing the porchase of the lipd, on which three farther instalments of I.E 820 each have to be poid. It must also be borne in mind that Sir Benest Cassel's generous codertaking to double all sobrcriptione, aroanting tbis year to the considerable som of L.E. 688, was only given for a period of tuo years. It is therefore greatly to be boped that the hospital funds will be generous'y sabsoribed to by the British and American communities of Cairo.

div.head: CAIRO CERCLE ARTISTIQUE.
div.p: A most snooessfal concert was given on Eanday night at the Cercle Artistique in aid of free teaching in lay schools. Mme. Baron, Davilloy, and Poncet, avd MM. B-oalair, Mery, Monteux and Moisson sang, and M. Comino gave two violin Bolog. The gem of he evening plas Mlle Devilloy's air from the "Barbier de Seville," which showed to the fall her perfeot taobniqne and exquisite t'mbre. Mme Baron änd M. Etoalais made a great saccess of the faal dao from "Sigard," and were induced to r.speat the last part of it. They finisbed o a phenomenally high notempo l048 tban D fit (above the line). Mm. Baron sang one of the acias from 'Hérodiado" with much power and fizeling. M. E calais war, as ever, brilliant ; ba bas socb a thoroagb control of bis volop, and bis great reverberating notes oannot bat delight all who care for real strength and mastery of --let as oallit 'heroio" singing. Mme Popoet Diade a great bit with "Margot a la Fontaine," and gave, as an oncore, "Bonne année." She pas most amaging and expressive. MM. Asoinnnn and M. zy were both p'ering. though 11. M zy might have chosen something less 'inirlitone'qne' than "La Cha'i'é," wbicb is rithor a bapbozurd kind of song, both in words apd in music. M. Cobat gave an interesting Izotore on Beethoven, and M. Comino'a violin solos were mach appreciated : the "Sordioi' rovement in the Strasate Zingarerqoe was charmingly played. M. Archimband acoum. panied with great taste all tbroogh. Mlle Charpentier and Mme Braocale were opfortare tely anable to be present throagh illness. M. (reen conducted the T mbola euotion with Togob energy and succe88. Two bopdred and forty foodds were realised thereby. The Khevivial Opera artistes are certainly heard to jaore advantage on these occasions : they have sio orobostra or recalcitrant chorus to damp their efforts, and they are singing to an appreviative and apiform andienos. They certainly deserved their sa00088.

div.head:
SPLENDID HOTELS.
CESSION DU FONDS SOCIAL
div.p: L'Assemblée Générale extraordinaire des Bulendid Hotels a eu lien hier après-midi dans les boreaux de MM de Menasce e figlio sous la présidence de M. Pélix de Mopasce.

L'obj-t de la convocation 6 ait la cession da tonds social. Bien qne les actionnaires présents taasont nombronz, la quantité des actions représentées n'était qne de 16,100 sor les 39,280 constituant la capital de la Société. Aucune résolution définitive d'ayant dono pa @•re prise, fapte do qnorum qui devait réanir les 8/4 da capital, il a été décidé de convo qnor ape nouvelle Agremblée Générale extra : ordinaire pour le 26 courant, à l'effat de statoer sar l'ordre no jour.

Le qnes'ion de la vente da New Khedivial a néanmoins été abordée. Après quelqnos explications données par le Président, Mo. Pados a la l'acte préliminaire de parte fuite à M. C. Bacos poar la somme de £112,500 qni permettrait de distribuer 10x actionnaires ane somme de £ 5 par action. L'acbetear prepdrait aussi à sa charge one gamme de £11 000 avancée par la maison de Mepasce e filio en compte courant à la Société et un petit proces pendant devant la Jaridiction Mixte.

Mr. le Baron Alfred de Menaste, répondant 80% observations de qnolqoes actionnaires, & dit 'qne les bénéfines dets probab'ee de l'exer. cioe en cours ne seront que de 4 à 5 000 £, va le grand nombre de dépenses de ler 6-ablissement qni viennent le grever ; qne l'entreprise 68t des plas promettantes, mais qne lo Conpeil a considéré l'éventnalité d'apo redoutable cononrredoe des Ritz Hotels jasta en f os le Now Khedivial, eventualité dont M. C. Bacos n'a pas manqué de se prévaloir dan les dégocia. rions et qui a décidé le Conseil & accepter ses offres."
Après quoi la grestion de la vente a 646 approuvée en principe à l'ananimité, à l'excep tion d'an actionnaire.

div.head: A L'INSTITUT EGYPTIEN
div.p: A la séance mensuelle de l'Institut Egyp. tien, tendo ao Caire londi soir, notre excellent confrère da Progrès," M. Galante, a fait une conférence très remarquable por la philologie 68pagnole. Antes avoir rappelé l'expolsion des israéliter d'Espagne en 1492, il a abordé la question des langues qni ont ea on rapport plus ou moins direot avec l'espagnol, soit l'bébren, l'arabe, l'araméon, le tare, le pergar, l'italien, le portaguie, le grec et le français, Le conférencier a ensuite parlé des travaux acomplis dans le domaine de la philologie expagnole et terminé en émettant quelqres réA xions sur l'avenir de l'espagnol en 0 jept et en Egypte. Parmi les journaux publiés dans cette løpgne en Egypte, il a signalé la Vara, fondés par lui et qui parait au Caire depois deux ans. M. Gilante, dans son intérøvgante communication, s'est révélé an philologas distingué et sa coaférende a été obaleuronsomoot applaudie.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Princess Mohamed Ibrahim has arrived at be Hotel Continental, Paris, for a long visit.

Lord and Lady Brackley (who have abandonad their contemplated trip to Egypt and were obliged to land at Marseilles owing to Lady Brackley having suffered so mach on the voyage) have gone to Hyères, and will not be back in England for some weeks. If Lady Brackley is well enoagh, they may possibly Tesame their journey to Egypt, in which case they will not retarn to London for two or three weeks.

The death is apnounced of the representative of a great Moslem family, head of the Dandotra section of the renowned Abbaside dynasty. Af er exercising fall governing powers over his State for only a little more than three years, bis Highness Nawab Mabomed Babawal Kban V., Nawab of Babawalpar, the leading Mabomedan principality of Northern Indis, has died in his 24th year far away from bis capital and his people. Io parsdance of a longcherished desire, he left Iodia towards the olose of last year, with a large retinde, on a pilgrimage to Mecca and Medioa. The toilsome journey, thoogh mitigated in its privations to the fullest extent that money could porobase, seems to have told upon the Nawab's delicate coostitation. Its drawbacks inoladed ten dage of weary qnarantide at Jeddab, a wire to the Snltan of Turkey asking fyr exemption from this delay having no effect. The Nawab died on board the vessel be bad chartered shortly after it bad left Adep for Bombay. The steamer returned to Aded, where the body was om. balmed and re-embarked for India.

We regret to announce the death of Mr. C. P. Schafer, the English representative of the well-known German firm of Kropp of Essen, which occurred at the Anglo American Hospita at Cairo on Sanday last. The deceased, who was 33 years of age, was brother of Mr. F. W Sobafer, m naging director of the Shannon, Limited. The late Mr. Schafer resided some yosroago at Alexandria, where he was a cotton exporter.

The general attitude of Russia on the eve of the opening of the Dama is possimistic. The only question discussed here is how long it will be before another dissolation. The Tsar will not attend at the opening. The Dowager Empress has started for England on a prolonged visit to Queen Alexandra.
(Reuter)

The Dama was quietly opened by the vicepresident of the Coonoil of the Empire. When the Ukage convening the Assembly was read the members on the Right rose and cheered the Emperor, the rest remained seated and silent. M. Golovin, Copatitational Democrat, was elected president. He said that all parties were united in the desire for the welfare of the nation. He hoped they would co-operate with tho Monarch in carrying out the social legis. lation indicated by the first Dama. (Reuter)

The Dama has been opened. M. Golovine, candidate of the Left, who was elected presidont by 331 votes against 91, expressed the hope that the Dama, apited in spite of its divergences of viowa, would succeed, in accord with the Tear, in deriving benefits from social legislation, in conformity with the principles of the first Doma. He added that thia institation, representing the nation, would dover die.
In the evening some rioting took place in Foorstadkia-stroot, where some workmen depaties delivered rovolationary barangaon. The patrola charged the orowd.
(Havas)

div.head:
THE TRANSVAAL MINISTRY.
BRITAIN'S TRUST IN THE BOERS.

div.p: The Transvaal Ministry was sworn in yesterday. General Botha, in the course of an interview afterwards, said that Great Britain would nover have cause to regret the trust she placed in the Boars. Mr. Hall, Treasurer, said that the fears that the Cabinet would damage the mining industry were groundless. (Reuter)

The Porte has approved and the Sultan bas sanctioned the drastio reforms in the Castom, Administration stipulated by the British Embassy as a preliminary to the three per cent. inorease in the Customs daties. The Porte gives formal assurances to carry out the reforms soropaloasly and promptly, but some improvements will take time to accomplish.
(Reuter)
King Edward has arrived and was greatly cheered. (Havas)
The "Gazette" apnounces that the Prince of Wales has been appointed Admiral.(Router)
Rov. Rojannan was Rector of the Armerian, not Amorioan, College bere. (Reuter)
Underwriters are largely interested in the Dakota cargo. At least £600,000 are involved Forty guineas per cent. was paid yesterday for reinspranon (Reuter)

div.head:
OUR NAVAL DEFENSES
THE TWO-POWER STANDARD.

div.p: HOUSE OF COMMONS -Mr. Robertson said that the Admiralty was of opinion that the maintenance of the two-power standard was adequately provided for at present. We had a88ared our saperiority as regards tbe latest types, namely, the Dreadnoughts and Invinoi. bles. In the spring of 1909 we would have 6 battleships and 3 oraisers completed, while France and Germany would have done. In 1910 we would have 9 battleships and 3 craisers ready, while France would have a battleships and Germany 4 battleships end 2 croisers.
(Reuter)

div.head: M KLOBUKOWSKI'S MISSION,
div.p: The Vairo correspondent of the "Globe," in referring to the approaching journey to Abyssinia of the French Minister to the Khedive, M. Klobakowski, draws attention to the oljeot of that mission. This is said to be obtaining Djibouti as a free port. Though hitherto a mere geographical point and of practically no account to Earopean politios, Djiboati has, among its neighbours on ib9 Red Sea and African littorals, been rapidly rising in the scale of importance, and information gathered in Cairo regarding the aims of M. Klobukowski's embassy proves that France lays great store by Djibou i, thut in fact the oreation of the port at the door to Ethiopia will be the main basis of M. Klobukowski's negotiations.

div.head: THE ADVANCE OF EGYPTIAN COTTON RATES
div.p: In bis weekly review of the Lancashire cotton trade in the "Financier," Mr. Tattersal states that yarns made from Egyptian cotton in the Bolton distriot and South Lancashire have been raised in, qaotation to meet the advances in Egyptian cotton. Users hardly know whioh way to tarn owing to the high rates which now have to be paid. Pressare for delivery is a featare, and certain producers seem to have oversold their production. The figer numbers in weft are decidedly strong, and extreme rates have been paid for quiok delivery. Combed desoriptions are practioally sold to the end of the year, and carded numbers are also very deeply ander contract.

div.head: LORD CROMER AND NUBAR
div.p: Mr. Edward Dicey in "The Egypt of the Fatore" has some interesting things to say about the relations of Lord Cromer with Nobar Pasha. He has one anecdote on the satject which deserves reproduction :

I can recall an iooident narrated to mo at one of the earliest meetings of the Commission of Enquiry. At this meeting, Nabar deliver d & very eloquent and detailed account of the reasons which had induced bim to establish the so-called International Tribunals, to the effect that these Courts were absolately inde. pendent of the Goveroment and therefore could be relied upon to administer justice. He added that justice was the basis of all genolie reform and of all true civilisation. When Nabar had fiojsbed bis speech, M. de Bli. gnières, then Minister of Pablic Works, rose and said he could not allow this speech to pars in silence without shaking the band of its anthor and thanking him for the services be had rendered not only to Egypt bat to humanity by the poble sentiments he had expounded 80 ably. Upon M. do Blignières sitting dowo, Major Baring, as he was thod, remarked "if talking was over they had better begin busi1988." This aneodote, wherber true or false, illastrates c'early the lack of mataal sympathy which, subsequent to oor military occupation, characterised the relations between Lord Cro mer and Nabar. The powerful imagination of the latter, bis marvellous command of langaage, his love for groat ideas and greater conceptions, his dislike of administrative details, his large views of expenditare and his sympathy with Oriental customs, Osages, and prejudices were all distastefal to bis British
colleagae, whose strict regard for rigid econoliny, whose preference for British laws and
Britieb jurisprudence exercised by British Consals and Jadges, and whose stiffness of manner presented a barrier against anyoordial co-operation between Nabar and our Consal General.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Lientenant Colonel A J. Chapman, Royal Dublin Fusiliers,commanding the 1st Battalion, Ezypt, bas been promoted brevet colonel, baving completed three years at the head of the battalion.

Colonel E. D. J. O'Brien, a well known Irish officer, has just retired from thecommand of the 14th King's Hassar's, Bangalore, on comple tion of his fuar years at its beard. He is Adoreeded by Brovet Colonel E. D. Browo-SyngeHotobinsor, V. C., the genond in command. Colonel Brown Synge-Hatobiogon hæ8 spent over twenty-three years in the cavalry arm, and won the cross "For Valoar" in the South Africạp War by taking Sergeant Hersoy, whose horro was shot, oat of action at Geluk, and assisting Lieutenant Browne, and carrying Lance Corporal Trumpeter Leigh out of action, all onder a very heavy rifle fire at 400 yards range. He was in all the fighting for the relief of Ladysmith.

Lieutenant R. W. Hadow, Royal Bigb. landers, who has been seconded in the gallant "Furty-twa" for service with the Khedire's forces, donded the phillabeg in May, 1901, and bad the advantage of seeing a good bit of campaigoing in the barassing operations in the Transvaal and Orange River Colony, for which he holds the Queen's medal with foar olasps.
The whole question of the oattiag down of the naval programme will come up on the di: cussion of the navol estimates, which will shortly be pablished. An interesting time is ex. pected.

div.head: SIR BENJAMIN STONE'S NILE PHOTOGRAPHER
div.p: Sir Benjamin Stone whose camera finds such constant employment during the Session on the Terrace of the House of Commons, bas (the "Times" romarks) jast resumed bis Parlia. mentary daties after a somowhat protracted visit to Egypt. Thanks to the valuable assist. ance of the British autboritieq, Sir Benjamin was able, in the course of his travels, to secure a opique collection of photographic records depicting the present aspeot of the great mona. ments and objeots of interest in the Nile basin, and reprodaoing scenes, insoriptions, and museum relios of the past, as well as pictures showing the present condition and the appostance of the native population, their village castoms, and modern improvements in their habits of life. Not the least interesting of the negatives taken are those of the besati-! fal raios of Kom Omba ; also those of the recently-excavated tombs of the Q 10008 near the plains of Thebes, which were explored two or three years ago by Icalian workers, and in which the coloured decorations are an fresh and brilliant as when first executed. The member for Enst Birmingham bas also taken some excellent photographs of the excavations and workings at Deir-elBabari, where M. Naville found the image of the sacred cow (now in the museum at Cairo), and where he has since opened a Royal tomb of great historio interest. Most noteworthy of all, however, are the views which Sir Benjamin bas taken in the Valley of the Tombs of the Kings, where Mr. Theodore Davies and Mr, Cirelly have just opened the remarkable tomb of Q 1000 Teie, this partionlar "and" happen. ing at the moment of Sir Be jumin's visit. The collection likewise includes faithful. pictares of the inscriptions at the Temple of Abydos, the wall sculptures of Karnak, Dendera, and the Rxmeseqm, the recently.opened tombs at Alex sndria, and the rock tombs above 48800an.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Awoord kui à midi at domio.). Aajoard'hai nouveau recul presgae général Il n'y a en hausse que les Splendid Hoteldon l'assemblée d'hier à approavé la cession de fonds social aax Rits, moyennant le rembour sement des actions au prix de 5 livres.

Cette attitado déplorableostattribade anxven tea incessantes da Caire età an solde important de liqaidation de fin de mois. Il en résalto qne les règlaments n'ont pas ea lieu le 4 garant, commme oela ett dû être le cas. Quelques-ans font aussi remonter le drainage de numéraira aux prix élevés atteints par le coton. Ces observations sont platôt de natare à rassurer le marché, car cos circonstances, allégades pour justifier la baisse, sont appelées à disparoître & bret délai.

Bo attendant, nous sommes en pleine de bandade. Pour ne citer que les valeurs les plus importantes, l'Agricole tombe à 9 3/16, ex-coapon, la National Bank & 27 3/4, la Delta Light à 11 3/8, la Daïra à 17 3/16, la Béhéra à 89'1/%, la Cassa di Sconto à 873 l'ancienne et 269 1/8 la noavolle, les Nuogoviob Hotels à 29 5/8, la Nile Land a 23 1/3, la Land Bank
8'13/16, l'Urbaine à 7 8/8 l'ancienne et 67/8 la nouvello, lo Comptoir 8 7 1,16 l'ancienne et 6 13/16 la nouvello, la Bauldings Lands à 5 11/16 et l'Union Fopoière à 6 1/16.
Parmi les petites va eurs, l'Investment s'of. fondre à 1 1/16 ot los Estates réactiondent à 2 8/8, vendears, ato.
Boa Quoap d'autres titres sont en baisse, comme on peat s'on convainore en consultant la oote.
Soals, les Splendid Hotels s'avancent très demandés à 4 5/8, en bonne tendance. Le rem. bodraemont à 5 livres étant en principe décidé par l'assemblée, ce prix ne tardera pas à être atteint.
Qiant à la tendance générale, elle ne peut qao s'améliorer, aussitôt que nous en aarons fini avec les reports et les liqaidations.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Lo Caire, Mardi 6 M1r8 1907. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londros a de DOQVoan baisse de 1/8 8 4 8/1 poor cent. Le Consolidé anglais a rétrogradé de 1/2 à 86 3/4. L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 102 1/2, de mone qne la National Bank à 28 1/8, la Daïra à 17 8/8 et la Delta Light à 11 1/2. L'Agricole a été cotée 9 3/8. ex.coopon.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien est demogró inobangé à 756. La Banque d'Athènes & avancé de : franos à 139.

loi, le marché des valears a présenté, ce matin, le même aspect pea satisfaisant qu'hier, à cette difference près que la séance a été beancoup plus calme, les transactions restreintes, atqne la loardear s'est étendue, cette fois, à toute la ligne de la cote.

Dans le compartiment des Banqnes, la Na. tiopal, offerte et délaissée, a rétrogradé à 28. L'Agricole, qui s'est traitée anjourd'hui ex. coupon de 9 shellinge, a o'taré fsible à 9 1/4. 6/16. La Casia di Soonto a reco!6 2?6. Le Comptoir Finanoier est revena à 7 3/16 et 88 part à 8 1/2. La Bw' qne d'Atbènes s'est aloordie à 136, la Banqne d'Orient à 133-134 et la Banqoo d'Abyssinie à 6. Les parts de la Société Générale Egyptienne ont été cotées 90-91 franos.

Le Crédit Foncier a été négligé à 751. La Daïra a fé,bi 17, la Béhéra à 40 et l'Union Foncière à 6 1/8. Los Allotments ont décliné à 8 1/8-8/16 et leur part à 116. L'Euterprise and Development a été négociée à 12 5/8, excoupon, et sa part à 20 1/4.

Les Entreprises Imm bilières et Travaux, toujours en batte aux hostilités dont nous avons parlé bier, ont olôturé à 7 7/8-8; c'est la toat le résultat obton 1 jaoqi'ici d'an départ outrageusement exploité; il faudra bientôt attendre les effets de l'approche d'an retoor. La part, qui a donné lieu à des transactions constantes, a été ramenée jusqu'à 105 pour terminer à 110, acheteurs.
L'Epargne Immobilière s'est tonne à 2 13/16 ; sa part a fini à 124. L'Express Nile a bré traitée à 5 1/4-5/16; sa part s'est maintenue à 130.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nongoviob ont réactionné à 30 3/16, les Egyp. tian à 12 9/16 et les Upper Egypt & 4 5/16. La part de fondateur National Hotel & c.Otaré à 70.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'ost tassés à 4 1/4. Les Estates ont faibli å ? 3/8 ; leur part a été mieux tende à 31 1/4-3/8. Los Hookor ont fléchi à 1 1/16, los New E yptiso à 35 sb., les Markets à 26 sh. 9 et les Ossis £ 0 15/16. Los Constructions se sont alourdies À 1 1/4.

Aa sujet de la sitaation da marché financier égyptien, nous détachons d'ane de nos correspondances d'Alexandrie, en date d'bier, les romarques suivantes qui poas paraissent de natare a intéresser vivement nos lecteurs :

" Le marasme et la loardear qui persistent depuis quelque temps sur le marché financier égyptien tandont visiblement à déconoorter ceux qui s'attendaient, à bon droit, à une sai. son aotive exooptionellement favorable. Tout, on effət, indiqaait an fort mouvement on avant: le développement vraiment merveilleux de l'agrioaltore et du commerce, one oampagne ootonnière sans précédent, la plus valae constanto dos terrains, sto.
" Or, nous avons va, sipon le contraire, da moins ane période d'arrêt, qui, bien à tort, a prodait an effet inquiétant sar les observateurs saperficioła. Ceox-ci ont été peu à peu amorés
croire que toat était perdo, que nous sum. ng manaoés d'ade orige dont les conséqaences praient graves, pour ne pas dire calamiteuses.

." De là le découragement né d'une période de stagnation on pla:ot de transition dont je voas ai exp046 les causes topiques dans une préoé lente correspondanoe; de id, la tendance, de la part de beaucoup de personnes, à liqaider même lears meillears valears, avec la convio. tion que ces valeurs avaient acquis lear maximam, qu'elles ne pourraient plus mouter avant lovgtemps, qu'elles devaient dès lors forcément descendre et ce dans ane mosare raineuse poar leurs détenteare.

" C'est là ane erreur profonde dont ne tarderont pas à s'apercevoir gaux qui ont 616 in. daits tomber daug le pièze tonda & lears appréhensions irraisonnées. On perd de vue, en effet, d'abord que ces titres ne 800t guère au-dessus de lear valeur intrinsèque, que nous 800mes à la genèse d'aue ère deaéveloppement pre-que sans exemple, que la richesse et la prospérité da pays s'accroissent à vae d'ail et q e, par conséquent, les bonnes entreprises finaucières et autres ont devant elles an ave sir brillant.

"Oo perd également de vue qne le porte feuille de nos capitalistes se compose de valeurs exclusivament égyptiennes, ce qui n'est pas le cas ailleurs, uù l'on plave bon argent eu titres de toas pays, et que, par conséquent, les boubes valeurs égyptiennes sunt appe.des progressi. vement à se classer en raison même de l'aug. mentation des capitaux dispouible*, lesquels trouvent diffic.lement aujourd'hui ar place. ment plus avantageux que celai que leur offrent ces valears.

"Eufiu il y a également liea de prendre en considération que los capitaux écraogors ton. dept de plas en plas à se placer en valeurs égyptiennes, qui donneut an revona laoratif en même temps que certain.

" l'outes dos ua 080s réunies doivent nécessairement finir par amener la baqsae. v'est, d'ailleurs, la sonde insae rationnelle et posole ble de la situaciou transitoiro pré soute, car Que baisse irait à l'eucoutre de toutes les éveutaslités logiquement admissibles. Au surplus, les prix de plus en plus élevés auxquels so vend le Coton sont, daus cet ordre d'idées, on signe précurseur et 90 fauteur dont il imporio de tenir compte."

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

For prospectus and particulars apply to the Manager.
Telegraphic Address: Central Salsomaggiore.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
